Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: I could see the lines on my mom’s face deepen as she sat at the kitchen table, rubbing her temples. Dad barely touched his dinner, lost in thought. I knew they were both carrying more than usual, and I felt the weight of their exhaustion settle on my shoulders. I wanted to sit with them, to ask if they were okay, to offer comfort—just be the child they needed right now. But my phone buzzed: another delivery notification. I had to get out the door, uniform on, packages in hand. The next stop was a moderately valuable item, and the app reminded me: “Signature required.” I couldn’t risk a missed delivery or a lost package—my job depended on it. As I laced up my shoes, I glanced back at my parents, torn. They needed me here, but my shift was starting, and customers were waiting. My heart pounded with the pressure of being in two places at once, knowing I couldn’t fully meet the expectations of either role.
